binaryOption.toolTip:
Enables stalling flash controller when flash is busy 
 When software needs to access the flash memory while a flash memory resource is being manipulated 
 by a flash command, software can enable a stall mechanism to avoid a read collision. 
 The stall mechanism allows software to execute code from the same block on which flash operations 
 are being performed. 
 However, software must ensure the sector the flash operations are being performed on is not 
 the same sector from which the code is executing. 
 This must be set only just before the flash operation is executed and cleared when the operation completes

fragment.variableTemplate: \t/** \t ** \t * Class used to do initialisation of Floating Point interrupts \t * \t * This class has a templated constructor that accepts a list of options to be configured. \t * The last parameter may be a previous instance used as a base for options. \t * Options not explicitly mentioned are cleared to 0 unless an previous value is given. \t * \t * @note This constructor may be used to create a const instance in ROM \t * \t * Example1: Create value in ROM \t * @code \t * const Mcm::FloatingPointIrqInit fpIrqInit { \t * // List of interrupts to modify \t * McmFpuDenormalIrq_Select, \t * McmFpuDivideByZeroIrq_Select, \t * }; \t * \t * fpIrqInit.configure(); // Configure Select interrupts and disable Unselect or absent interrupts \t * fpIrqInit.enableInterrupts(); // Enable Select interrupts (others are unaffected) \t * fpIrqInit.disableInterrupts(); // Disable Select interrupts (others are unaffected) \t * @endcode \t * \t * Example2: Inline example using a base value + modifications \t * @code \t * Mcm::FloatingPointIrqInit{ \t * // List of interrupts to modify \t * McmFpuDenormalIrq_Select, // This interrupt is enabled \t * McmFpuDivideByZeroIrq_Unselect, // This interrupt is disabled \t * Mcm::DefaultFloatingPointIrqInitValue // Other interrupts are determined by this value (determined by configure.usbdmProject) \t * }.configure(); \t * \t * // The above is equivalent to: \t * Mcm::DefaultFloatingPointIrqInitValue.configure(); \t * Mcm::FloatingPointIrqInit {McmFpuDenormalIrq_Select}.enableInterrupts(); \t * Mcm::FloatingPointIrqInit {McmFpuDivideByZeroIrq_Select}.disableInterrupts(); \t * @endcode \t */ \tclass FloatingPointIrqInit { \t \tpublic: \t /// Mask indicating bits to set or clear in register \t uint32_t %registerName = 0; \t \tpublic: \t /** \t * configure Floating Point interrupts as specified in the constructor \t * ..._Unselect or absent values will disable interrupts \t * ..._Select values will enable interrupts \t */ \t inline void configure() const { \t %register = %registerName; \t } \t \t /** \t * Enable Floating Point interrupts as specified in the constructor \t * ..._Unselect or absent values are ignored \t * ..._Select values will enable interrupts \t */ \t inline void enableInterrupts() const { \t %register = %register|%registerName; \t } \t \t /** \t * Disable Floating Point interrupts as specified in the constructor \t * ..._Unselect or absent values are ignored \t * ..._Select values will disabled interrupts \t * This allows the same FloatingPointIrqInit to be used to enable/disable a set of interrupts \t */ \t inline void disableInterrupts() const { \t %register = %register&~%registerName; \t } \t \t /** \t * Read the current Floating Point interrupt settings from hardware registers \t */ \t void readConfig() { \t %registerName = %register & %mask; \t } \t \t /** \t * Copy Constructor \t */ \t constexpr FloatingPointIrqInit(const FloatingPointIrqInit &other) = default; \t \t /** \t * Constructor \t */ \t constexpr FloatingPointIrqInit() { \t } \t\n
